name: Moderator Kathy
comment info: Thank you, this is wonderful.

name: Neville Longbottom
comment info: As we examine the graphical representation of our current Supreme Court justices, we cannot help but notice the fact that more conservation justices have been appointed by Republicans and the more liberal justices were all appointed by Democrats. This graphic displays the partisan divide in our country that has infiltrated the highest court in our judicial branch, which is intended to be non-partisan.

name: Emma
comment info: I notice that Democrats tend to be more liberal while the Republicans tend to be conservative. Also, as time goes on, there is a wide spread between conservative and liberal. Instead of being all bunched together, there are different levels of how conservative and liberal someone is. Democratic nominees have also gotten more liberal overtime as republican nominees tend to stay at the same level of conservative. I wonder what exactly is the Martin-Quinn score and exactly what criteria goes into choosing how liberal or conservative one is. What variables are being taken into account? What would eighteenth century politicians fall on this graph? A possible title for this graph could be “Looking at Supreme Court Nominees before Kavanaugh.”

name: Jenna & John
comment info:
What did we notice:
- That all of the liberal justices got more liberal over time
- Thomas started out as very republican and has stayed that way over time
- Kennedy serves as the justice very close to the median and is a swing vote (yet he is still on the conservative side of the Martin- Quinn Score
- The downward trend of liberalism across almost all justices

What did we wonder:
- Where Kavanaugh fits in on this graphic
- With a new justice on the supreme court, how will the median justice line shift
- Will the downward trend towards liberalism continue with a new justice
- How to measure a Martin-Quinn Score

name: Drew and Lucas
comment info:
1. The conservative justices got more liberal during the mid-2000s but recently got more conservative while the liberal justices have gotten more liberal.
2. I wonder the methods in which they use to score this graph and how it is scaled.

name: Allie + Madison + Davi
comment info: We noticed right off the bat that the median Supreme Court justice is more conservative, which wasn't super surprising. We were wondering if the median justice will follow its downward trend and be more liberal in the future, or if the current administration will disrupt this pattern. Our new article name: Where does SCOTUS really stand?

comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice Kennedy is in bold and pops out
Big difference between Clarence Thomas and Sotomayor
Liberal ones are mostly farther from median than conservative
• What do you wonder?
Why people strayed more from the median as time goes on.
I wonder how they calculate how conservative or liberal someone is.
• What might be going on in this graph?
In recent times the country has become more split and republicans who once were at the median are not and democrats have become more liberal.

name: Alissa and Veronica

comment info: In this graph, we wonder why the people nominated by a democrat become more liberal over time. We notice that this graph shows how many years the supreme court judges have been in that specific position. We also notice the red line represents people nominated by a republican and blue represents people nominated by a democrat, but there is one yellow line and we can conclude this means that is the middle or both. We can also see that there is more conservative than liberal people.

comment info:
I noticed that thomas voted for a republican but he was more conservative than the rest. I also noticed there was more republican than democrats. some questions ive had was what does the median justice line mean? i thought maybe it meant that they dont go for republican or democrats maybe they are independent. In this graph is showing the common trend of how the more conservative justices are being nominated by republicans, and how the more liberal justices are being nominated by democrats.
Title- differnce between republicans and democrats

I wonder why there is a yellow line. I also wonder what the yellow line means by median justice. A good title for this graph would be Ranking of the congress that were nominated. comment info: starting in 1988 there more people that considered thomas then other

comment info: I noticed that Thomas was nominated by a republican and he's way more conservative than all of the other justices nominated by republicans. I wonder if the yellow line represents an independent justice and why the democrat elected justices are going towards the median justice.A good title for this graph would be Republican and Democratic Justice Nominations, i believe this is a good headline because it directly explains what is going on in the graph

name: E. Wild
comment info:
We notice that this graph is for Supreme Court Justices, the lines in red are nominated by Republican and the blue are nominated by Democrats. Where the lines are positioned on the graph, represent which is more Conservative or Liberal. The Republican nominees are more conservative while the Democrats are more liberal. The graph is also skewed Republican/Conservative due to the median being positioned at +2.
We wonder how the graph would be affected if there were five Liberal justices instead of four. Also, what is the Martin-Quinn score?
Based off the graph’s key, the graph can be named “Political association of Supreme Court Justices”.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@E. Wild
I see you are paying attention to the median in the graph.  What does this median tell us?  Is there a trend in this measure of center?

name: reniqua
comment info: I notice the graph is talking about republicans and democrats.They are more republicans than democrats and if they are about the line they are more conservative than liberal. I wonder what the yellow line means. A good title for this graph would be "People in the supreme court" because its about the people and what they represent.

name: G. Patchett
comment info:
1)	We noticed that the graph is a comparison between nine Supreme Court justices and their Martin-Quinn score from 1988 to 2017. According to the graph, the justices on the conservative side were nominated by republicans, and vice versa for the justices on the liberal side.
2)	How exactly does one test for a Martin Quinn score? Is the Supreme Court biased as a result of differing political beliefs? How does the data on the graph fluctuate? How does the data shown in the graph affect the United States as a whole?
3)	“Political Bias of Supreme Court Justices”: Based on the graph, majority of the data shows up on the conservative side. The data depicted on the graph prompts the question of whether or not political ideals or beliefs affect decisions of justices in the Supreme Court.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@G. Patchett
Great observations!  What do you think it means to be "on the conservative side" according to this graph?  You posed a great question about the fluctuations as well.  What might indicate whether a judge is more conservative or more liberal (in order to explain the fluctuations)?

name: A.Patterson
comment info:
We noticed the fluctuations in the way the justices voted, and that the data only goes back to 1988, which brought us to wonder: why only 1988??  We also noticed that the nominations are partisan and that the liberal-leaning justices have been nominated more recently. What caused the fluctuations in the ways the justices voted that made them more liberal or conservative? 

We decided to call this graph " Toeing a Wide Line" , because we noticed that the justices scores were fairly spread out instead of being close together. We concluded that the fluctuations could have been influenced by the public opinion and changing times as well as the justices point of view on society and government.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@A.Patterson
Great question about the decision to only go back to 1988 for the data!  This list on Wikipedia might give you some insight.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Justic...

name: Leo
comment info: I noticed they are separated by democracy and that Thomas. is more conservative, I wonder how the "Martin Quinn Score" works, The tittle i would but is " The Power of the Supreme Court", It lists all the supreme justices and the graph shows how uneven the court is.

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
As we were examining this graph, the Senate has been discussing the newest nomination to the Supreme Court – Judge Brett Kavanaugh.  Now that you have focused on this graph, I bet you were thinking about how this appointment will affect the ideology of the Court.  Well, this graph gives you some information to make a conjecture.  What do you think?

The headline from Yasmine of East Boston proclaims, “More Liberal Society, More Liberal Supreme Court!” “ Kyle of Naperville asks a very relevant question, “Judiciary Branch Nominations Swayed by Perspectives in Political Parties?”   Good noticing and wondering leads to snappy headlines.

Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ replies. Dig deeper into what the graph shows.  Perhaps you will find more things to notice, wonder, claim or conjecture. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, October 4, to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and two Stat Nuggets. And join us next Wednesday, October 10 for the next "What's Going On In This Graph?”  Signing off – Sharon in Boston and Erica Chauvet in Pittsburgh, PA. 

Visit the "What's Going On In This Graph?" archives to keep responding. Hope to see you next week.

name: Melody
comment info: The democrats seem to be nominated more recently. I wonder what "Median justice" means.

name: F. Gaynor
comment info: We noticed that it is a primarily government and political graph. We wonder how time has changed people’s political views and we wonder how this graph is used in politics.  The main idea or headline of this graph could be something along the lines of “How Political Views Change Over Time”.

replies.name: M

name: J. Lewis
comment info:
I notice that there are more justices nominated by republicans than democrats, and that over time most everyone’s line has gone down towards the liberal half of the graph.
I wonder why everyone is leaning towards liberalism, and what prompted this graph to be made.
This graph could be named “slow decline of conservatives in our courts?”

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @J. Lewis - Nice job at backing your graph name up using evidence from the graph. Check back tomorrow to see the graph in the context of its original article!

name: I.Roth
comment info:
What do you notice?
We noticed that the more conservative the nominees are means they are more likely to be nominated by a Republican. Also the more liberal nominees are more likely to be nominated by a Democrat. In the years between 1988 and 1992 there was low amount of Democratic nomination compared to the Republican nomination.  

What do you wonder about?

 What might be going on in this graph?

name: N. Ford
comment info:
What do you notice?
There have been more conservative justices nominated. We also noticed that justices nominated by democrats tend to be more liberal, while justices nominated by Republicans tend to be more conservative.
What do you wonder?
Will the Martin Quinn score start to migrate down towards the more democrat side, due to the fact that the Republican nominees have been in office for longer and will probably start to retire sooner.
What might be going on in this graph?
The Supreme Court has started to make more democratic decisions, this is shown in a dip in Republican nominee’s decisions toward the more liberal section of the graph. As society makes more liberal decisions so does the Supreme Court. A title that would be fitting for this graph would be “Is the Supreme Court becoming more liberal in its decision making?”.

replies.name: M

name: Cole, Matt, Brigitte

name: Kyle B
comment info:
Judiciary Branch Nominations Swayed by Perspectives in Political Parties?

I noticed that there are more selections for the republican party in the judiciary branch, yet they are represented, in the graph, more extreme in their party compared to the democrats. I also noticed that the supreme court justice, Kennedy, is shown as the closest to the Martin-Quinn score. Does this mean that Kennedy is has the least amount of a political perspective on cases?
I wonder how the creators of this graph view politics and their political stance. If there was a bias, the graph could be manipulated to emphasize a point trying to be made.
In this graph, it appears as though the creators want to show political affiliation in the justice system. It could be showing how perspectives can affect decisions made or who will be nominated.

replies.comment info:

Is it solely based on their decisions on cases?

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Alejandra I have also noticed that they stood further from the median justice. Although I agree that only one justice has come close to the median, but it get me thinking if any would ever touch? I think that the title you had picked would work perfectly for this infograph!

@Alejandra
That’s a good question, “Is (the Martin-Quinn score) based on decisions on cases?”  What do you think?  Maybe a search might yield an answer.

name: Cory
comment info: I notice that, by in large, Supreme Court Justices have been getting more and more divided (according to the Martin-Quinn score), just like our country as a whole. I wonder what the methods of determining the political ideology of the present Supreme Court Justices. Also, I wonder why Supreme Court Justices, if they are supposed to be relatively neutral (and are not supposed to factor their beliefs into their court cases) are so vastly different in political affiliation. I think this graph should be called The Political Ideologies of Supreme Court Justices Over Time.

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Cory I agree that as time is progressing the country is getting more divided. George Washington in his farewell address was wise in predicting that two opposing political factions would create tensions and problems for our country, and I think it is evident in the media and the current events today about how our country is divided.

name: Carson
comment info: It is interesting to see that Democratic nominees tend to be moderate when they are first nominated while the Republican nominees are usually already fairly conservative. Either way, the justices become more deeply rooted in their beliefs which polarizes the Supreme Court. I wonder how it is decided how liberal or conservative each justice is. Is it based off of an actual test they take occasionally, is it based off of their leanings on cases?

name: Laney and Nanseera
comment info: This graph shows the tenures of current supreme court justices and their political views throughout their years in office. We noticed that Bobby Kennedy follows the median justice trend line pretty consistently beyond 2005. Clarence Thomas has remained quite conservative since the start of his term. The democratic justices seem to be becoming more liberal as the years go on. We looked up the Martin-Quinn score and found that the conservative and liberal nature of the justices is measured relatively to the other justices. Therefore, justice's views themselves might not be changing, but rather their liberal or conservative leanings in relation to each other.

replies.comment info:
@Laney and Nanseera
Cassandra from Maryland noticed two variables in this graph -- nominated by Republican or Democrat and more conservative or liberal.  You noticed that the graph shows the years that justices sat on the bench.  Most importantly, you noticed the ideological trend of individual justices and of conservative and liberal justices as groups.  You must have wondered, “What is a Martin-Quinn score?”    Would you share with us where you found your information?  The fact that the score compares justices’ ideologies to each other is key to understanding this graph.  Thank you for bringing this up at the beginning of our discussion.

name: Trae Young
comment info: I find it interesting that the Democratic nominees are closer to the middle while Republican nominees are so extreme. Also it is interesting how Kennedy lined up on the median line from about 2005 to the present.

replies.comment info:
@Trae Young
From what you have noticed, how about giving us a catchy headline what captures your ideas?

replies.name: K
replies.comment info:
@Trae Young
I agree with the it being interesting about the Democratic nominees being closer to the median justice. I wonder if this is the views of the individual justices or the views of the Democratic party as a whole. I also wonder what this could potentially affect in the future with other options.

name: Cassandra
comment info: It seems to be that the graph shows changes in Republican and Democratic politician's views over time. The Republicans seem to be drawn towards conservative views, while the Democrats are leaning towards liberal views. Which seems rather odd, considering that Liberalism and Conservationism are two completely different political parties from the Republican and Democratic parties.

replies.comment info:
@Cassandra
You mention two variables in this graph – Nominated by Republican or Democrat and More Conservative or Liberal.  What other variables does this graph show?

name: Maddie
comment info: I notice that over time liberal nominees are becoming even more liberal. It appears that  conservative nominees are about the same through the years. I wonder what the median justice is, but if I had to guess I would say it's the midpoint of the two party ideals. I also wonder how the scores are determined, because being liberal or conservative isn't generally ranked on a scale.

replies.comment info:
@Maddie
You’re looking at the trends of individual justices’ ideology and how they compare to each other over time, which is critical when examining time series graphs.  To learn about the scale used to compare justices’ ideology, search for “Martin-Quinn score”.  One of the interesting features of this scale is that it measures relative ideology.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Maddie
I completely agree on what you had noticed. I also saw that how the people are slowly becoming more liberal shown on the graph

name: Christian
comment info: Cool graph, but what does it mean?

replies.comment info:
@Christian
I wondered the same thing when I first saw this graph.  To help you figure out any graph, start with asking yourself what you notice.  If you do this with others in your class, the ideas of others should lead you to additional insights.  Then, ask yourself what you wonder about the graph.  From this start, I bet you’ll have some ideas of “what does it mean. “Let us know what you come up with.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Christian it is showing many factors such as which justices are more lib. vs. Rep. Also shows what party nominated them.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?”.  The Supreme Court has been in the news because of the Senate is holding confirmation hearings for a new justice.  But, Monday, October 1 – “the first Monday in October”, was the opening day of the 2018 session of the Supreme Court of the United States, or SCOTUS as it is often called.  We thought this was a good time to examine the ideology of the justices.  Study the graph and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.) 

	What do you NOTICE in this graph? 

	What do you WONDER? What are you curious about?

	What’s GOING ON in this graph?
Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.

Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: Jane
comment info: I notice that the graph depicts the supreme court justices, what party they were nominated by, and how liberal or conservative they are on a “Martin-Quinn score” scale. There also is a “median justice” which I think refers to how overall liberal/conservative the bench as a whole is. It also shows how overtime the justices have shifted on the political scale. Some start pretty centrist and as the years pass become more liberal. Others start centrist and as the years pass become more conservative. I think the graph is simply referring to how liberal and conservative our U.S. Supreme Court is. I am curious about how the dates on the x axis of the graph work. Do those refer to when the justice was appointed to the supreme court? Justice Ginsburg was appointed in 1980 and her line starts around the 90s. Also what is a “Martin-Quinn score”. How is it measured? A catchy headline for the graph could be “Justice is Served”.
